files.text:
Suffixes -yama, -kasai, and
-kashamai
Oni Joi

 Suffix -yama
The suffix -yama indicates the negation of a verb. We conjugate it with a tense following
the suffix.
Example 1:
Ati + -yama ⟶ Ayama + -ai (present tense) ⟶ Ayamai (don’t do, present) The double “a”
gets contracted.
“Enra Ayamai” ⟶ I don’t do. (Transitive pronoun used for transitive verb)
Example 2:
Ati + -yama ⟶ Ayama + -ke (resent past tense) ⟶ Ayamake (didn’t do just now)
“Enra Ayamake” ⟶ I didn’t do, just now. (Transitive pronoun used for transitive verb).

 Suffix -yama
Example 3:
Kinanti + -yama ⟶ Kinanyama + -ai (present tense) ⟶ Kinanyamai (don’t purge,
present) The double “a” gets contracted.
“Enra Kinanyamai” ⟶ I don’t purge. (Transitive pronoun used for transitive verb)
Example 4:
Nashiti + -yama ⟶ Nashiyama + -ai (present tense) ⟶ Nashiyamai (don’t bathe,
present) The double “a” gets contracted.
“Eara Nashiyamai” ⟶ I don’t bathe. (Intransitive pronoun used for intransitive
verb)

 Suffix -yama
In icaros (and also daily life), we can hear this suffix when our teacher is
giving us advice about what not to do. In this case the suffix -yama will be
followed by the suffix -we.
Example 5:
Ochati + -yama ⟶ Ochayama + -we ⟶ Ochayamawe (don’t sin!). This is a
line to protect the student from temptations during dieta.

 Suffix -kasai/kashamai
The suffix -kasai is composed of 2 parts:
-kas (want, desire) + -ai (present tense) ⟶ want in the present
Example 1:
Ati + -kasai ⟶ Akasai (want to do in the present)
“Enra akasai” ⟶ I want to do. (Transitive pronoun used for transitive verb)

Example 2:
Nashiti + -kasai ⟶ Nashikasai (want to bathe in the present)
“Eara nashikasai” ⟶ I want to bathe. (Intransitive pronoun used for
intransitive verb).

 Suffix -kasai/kashamai
The suffix -kashamai is composed of 2 parts:
-kasham (don’t want, don’t desire) + -ai (present tense) ⟶ not want in the present
Example 1:
Ati + -kashamai ⟶ Akashamai (do not want to do in the present)
Enra akashamai ⟶ I do not want to do. (Transitive pronoun used for transitive
verb)
Example 2:
Nashiti + -kashamai ⟶ Nashikashamai (do not want to bathe in the present)
Eara nashikasai ⟶ I do not want to bathe. (Intransitive pronoun used for
intransitive verb).

 Bena Joi
Jisonti ⟶ to urinate
Raometi ⟶ to medicate oneself
Senen ati ⟶ to finish a process.
Tsokasti ⟶ to become scattered
Shinanti ⟶ to think, remember
Toeti ⟶ to break
Masa shinanti ⟶ to worry
Akinti ⟶ to help
Raketi ⟶ to fear
Koiranti ⟶ to take care

Patax ⟶ besides
Kochi ⟶ pork, pig
koriki ⟶ money
bocho ⟶ full
Onsa ⟶ dangerous

 Other suffixes or expressions
Suffixes:
-non (v)⟶ will do (not immediately, announcement)
“mia benxonon” ⟶ you will heal
-oma (n) ⟶ without
“korikioma” ⟶ without money
-ira (adj) ⟶ to the extreme, very “bochoira” very full
metsaira “very pretty”
Expression:
ixon ⟶ “once being, as a result of being”
“korikioma ixon” ⟶ as a result of being without money

 A: Eara jisonkasai!
B: Raobo patax
jisonyamawe!
In the Shipibo-Konibo tradition it is believed that urinating next to a master plant will upset the plant spirit
and cause it to turn against the person, even causing disease or harm.

 A: Eara
raomekashamai
B: Rakeyamawe.
Raomewe. Mia
benxonon.

 A: Enra moa sama
senen akasai!
B: Tsokasyamawe.
Koshi akin
shinanwe!

 A: Enra kochi
pikasai!
B: Sama
toeyamawe!
In the Shipibo-Konibo tradition eating pork severly crosses one’s master plant dieta. Dreaming of broken glass signifies
that the dieta will be broken in some manner.

 A Jawekeskarin mia?
B: Ea riki masa shinani,
korikioma ixon.
A: Masa
shinanyamawe! Enra
mia akinai.

 A: Enra oni
bochoira
xeakashamai.
Kikin onsa riki!

Enra mia koiranai.

 Icaro: Nokon Yora Panaban
Nokon yora panaban
Joiyabi panati
Ramitima abanon
Pisi piaxbikaya
Jawe iyosmakaya
Ea xawebiribi

I will protect my body
Protecting all my prayers
So they do not get distorted
As soon as I consume what smell rotten
Nothing happens
to me, the one and only gentleman

Jakonmabo piaxbi
Jawe iyosmakaya
Itsaboki piaxbi
Jawetianbikaya
Ramiyosma medico
Ea xawebiribi

Once I consume what is incompatible
Nothing happens
As soon as I consume what has a pungent smell
Never
does it get distorted
me, the one and only gentleman

Ea kanobanonri
Bewakanbi ibanon
Inin ayontaana
Koshibira panati
Tsonbibiki merati
Meratima abanon

I will connect myself
I will sing With these songs
Having aromatized fully
The powerful protection
for no one to find me
No one will find me

Icaro Writing Excercise
Week 10
Oni Joi
Joi

 1.Protector Spirit
Protector Spirit

PLURAL:
Nokon sontarobokan
Acerobo Jonibo
SINGULAR:
Nokon joxo leonkan
Nokon joxo caballo
Nokon joxo osokan
Nokon joxo/wiso roninkan
Nokon wiso inokan
Nokon manan acero, joni manan acero

Translation

PLURAL:
My actual soldiers
Steel People (robots)

SINGULAR:
My actual white lion
My white horse
My actual white bear
My actual white/black anaconda
My actual black jaguar
My steel mountain, my steel mountain
people

Key Words and Suffixes
Nokon - My
Sontaro - soldier
Acero - steel (spanish)
Joni - person
Joxo - white
Leon - lion (spanish)
caballo - horse (spanish)
oso - bear (spanish)
ronin - anaconda
Wiso - black
Ino - jaguar
wiso ino - black jaguar
manan - mountain
-bo (suffix, noun): plural
-kaya (suffix, noun): true, without
doubt
-kan (suffix, noun): actual

 2. Call them and become aligned
Will call them, summon them

after they are placed

Kena kenabanonri - will immediately call
Kena kenashamanban - will immediately
call excellently

PLURAL:
joyobaintaanara - having placed themselves in line along the way
joyoaketaanara - having placed themselved in line all around
chankabaintaanara - having stood up along the way
chankaaketaanara - having stood up all around
SINGULAR:
jishtimayontaanara - having made it fully appear
chankamayontaanara - Having made it stand up fully

Kenati (v, t) - to call, summon
-banon (suffix, v): announcement, immediate
-ri (suffix, v): emphasis
-shaman (suffix, v): doing so excellently
-ban (suffix, v): announcement, immediate

Joyoti (v,i) - to place oneself in line
chankati (v,i) - to stand in 2 feet
Jishtiti (v,i) - to appear
-bain (suffix, v) - to do along the way (transitive verbs or plural intransitive)
-ake (suffix, v) - to do around
-taana (suffix, v) - having done so...
-ma (suffix, v) - make an action
-yon (suffix, v) - do an action fully
-ra (suffix, v) - emphatic

 3. Tell them to take care
I tell them

to take care of the space/people

I express my ask

Koirantiki yoikin

Yoi yoibainkin

“I make them listen to my
words”

“I am telling them to take care”

“I am telling them along the way”

Nokon - my
joi - word, voice
ninkati - to listen

Koiranti - to take care
yoiti - to speak, say

yoiti- to speak

Nokon joi ninkamai

-ma (suffix, v): make an
action happen
-ai (suffix, v): present

ki (suffix, v): emphasis, towards
-kin (suffix, v): present participle, more
descriptive and external

-bain (suffix, v): to do along the way
-kin (suffix, v): present participle, more
descriptive and external

 4. Tell them to guard the house
Category

Plural

Singular

Closing Words

Analysis

Xobo katemabanon
Katemayontaanara
Jabaon jawekiyabi
Pishayontaanara
Mana manamabanon

xobo - house
kateti - to surround
jabaon - their
jaweki - objects
pishati - to release
manati - to wait

“Will make them surround the house,
having made them surround fully,
with all their gear,
having released it fully,
I will make them wait”

-ma (suffix, v): make an action happen
-banon (suffix, v): immediate announcement
-yon (suffix, v): to do an action fully
-taana (suffix, v): having done so
-ra (suffix): emphasis
-yabi (suffix, n): with all

xobo mayamabokin
maya mayamabokin
“I am making it circle around the house as I go,
making it circle around the house as I go”

xobo - house
mayati - to circle, go around, swirl
-ma (suffix, v): make an action happen
-bo (suffix, v): do as you go
-kin (suffix, v): present participle, more descriptive and external

 5. Sequence for inanimate objects
Shipibo-Konibo

Nokon pana espejo
Espejobo panabo
Nichin nichinbainkin
Nichinyontaanara
Xobo katemabanon
Katemayontaanara

English translation

“My protector mirror
mirror protectors
I planting them along the way
having planted them fully
I will make them surround the hose
having made them surround the
house fully”

Key Words and Suffixes
Nokon - my
Pana - protector
Espejo - mirror (spanish)
Nichinti - to implant, place firmly, very
rooted
Xobo - house
Kateti - to surround
-bo (suffix, n): plural
-bainkin (suffix, v): doing along the way
-yon (suffix, v): do action fully
-taana (suffix, v): having done so fully
-ra (suffix, v): emphasis
-ma (suffix, v): make an action happen
-banon (suffix,v): immediate
announcement

3/5

Introduction to the middle
-xonOni Joi

 Suffix -xonWe have already shared one type of suffix -xon with the meaning “once it has been done...”
This suffix either goes at the end of a word or right before an emphatic.
However, there is another kind of -xon- which we call the “middle -xon-”. This suffix usually goes
right after the root of a verb and needs other suffixes to follow up (tenses, commands, etc.).
The meaning of this middle -xon- is “to do something for another or in service of another”.
This suffix is commonly used in both day-to-day language and icaros.
In the icaros, we mostly see this suffix used when the onanya or healer is directing their icaro to
another person. You will hear the use of this suffix often when your onanya sings for you.
This suffix requires always a transitive pronoun (En, min, jan, etc.) before. It makes all verbs
transitive in nature, since we are doing an action FOR ANOTHER.

 Examples:
Let’s take the verb Ati, to do.
Ati + -xon- = Axon + -banon = Axonbanon ⟶ will do it for another
En mia axonbanon = I will do it for you (suffix -banon does not require a -ra in the pronoun)
Very common icaro expression “En mia axonban” (I will do it for you) to express that the onanya will
do the medicine work for the patient.
Ati + -xon- = Axon + -ai = Axonai ⟶ I do it for another (present)
Enra mia axonai = I do it for you. (suffix -ai does require a -ra in the pronoun)

 Examples:
Let’s take the verb Iti, to be.
Iti + -xon- = Ixon + -banon = Ixonbanon ⟶ will be it for another
En mia Ixonbanon = I will be it for you (suffix -banon does not require a -ra in the pronoun)
This is a very common icaro expression “En mia Ixonban” (I will do it for you) or “mia ixonbanonri” to
express that the onanya will sing for the patient.
In this case the verb “to be” is functioning as a general verb that encompases many intransitive
actions such as the verb “bewati”, to sing.
In the same way that in English we use the verb “to do” to speak very generally about any set of more
specific actions, in Shipibo we use the verb “Iti” to be to speak generally about intransitive actions,
and the verb “Ati” to do, to speak more generally about transitive actions.

 Bena Joi
Inkaiko Rao ⟶ Marosa
Jawebi ⟶ nothing
Kepenti ⟶ to open
Keyoti ⟶ to finish, eliminate (Keyo- + -res (purely this action )+ -ai (present) =
Keyoresai⟶ its all finishing)
Weninti ⟶ to make someone stand (different from “weniti - to lift yourself up”).
Rome xei ⟶ tabacco ciraggettes (rome - tobacco, mapacho. xei - roll)
Beti ⟶ to bring
Kenti ⟶ pot
Iwe ⟶ heavy
Boti ⟶ to take

-kan in “ramakan” is acting as an “and” for “and now?”. “Jise” translates as “there you go”, and “irake” as “thank you.”

Shipibo-Konibo
Master Plant Dieta
By Wexa Metsa and Macarena

 Irake!
Thank you!

 What is a Master Plant Dieta?
A process by which a person aims
to establish an encounter with the
plant spirit for the purposes of
learning traditional doctoring or
healing from a particular illness.
The first 3 months signify the
welcoming of the doctor to the
relationship or healing for the
patient. It takes about 1 year to
establish a complete relationship
with 1 plant.

 It takes time and devotion to build
true mastery in traditional doctoring.
Modern shorter diets are for healing
and the expansion of our gifts and
conciousness. If you want to have a
true encounter with the spirit you can
continously diet 1 plant until you meet
the spirit.

 Who are the master plants?
They are highly intelligent
beings.
Behind the plant, there is a
spirit, or ibo. A human
form. The goal is to get to
meet the ibo.

 Master plants teach humans about the
blueprints of life. How to live well. How to open
our gifts.
They mirror to us our sacred design. We are all
beings with a material form, an energetic
dimension, and a divine conciousness.
Who are the plants?
They are ultimately a form of Nete Ibo. God. In
the dieta, we get to meet God. Everything is a
manifestation of God.

 The Ibo does not show itself at first. In visions or
dreams:
First it shows itself in symbols (lights, designs,
people that we know).
Then it begins to manifest itself in more
sophisticated forms (jaguars, anacondas, people)
Then comes the Ibo, a human form.
The Ibo is the NETE IBO. The ultimate boss of the
game.

 How do we learn
from Master Plants?
1.We abstain from certain foods, drinks, behaviors,
and exposure to blood to establish the container.
2.We drink the master plant tea.
3.We begin to get to know the plant through
interacting with our dreams, visions, and real-life
experiences.
4.We receive gifts and overcome tests.
5.If we diet long enough, we get to encounter the
plant spirit. This is the moment where we express
why we are here. Either we are welcomed into their
world for our doctoring practice, or we are gifted
with healing.

This is like entering a romantic
relationship

 Dream interaction
Dreams are the main way in which a
dietero interacts with their master
plant.
Plants speak in codes. To master the
codes helps you have fluent
communication with your plant.
Imagine wanting to be in a
relationship with someone and not be
able to communicate?

 Vision decoding
Ceremonial visions are like
dreams. They come in codes.
The dietero learns how to
interact and respond to
those codes in order to
deepen their relationship
with the plant spirit

Art by Pablo Amaringo

 Gifts and Tests
Through our dreams and visions
we recieve both GIFTS, and TESTS.
Gifts: clothes, rings, watches.
Tests: challenging situations
The task is to analyze the gift or
test.
Art by Luis Tamani

 Real-life experiences
Scenarios in our waking
time are also a part of the
plant dieta container and
the teaching of the
master plant.

 Being welcomed by
the Spirit
Taming a spirit, actual marriage in
dreams, meeting a very important boss,
receiving keys, etc are very significant
codes that mean our welcome into a
new agreement and life. It is like
marriage. Entering a new lifestyle.
Meeting the actual spirit in human form
and expressing why you are there.
Art by Luis Tamani

 Once you receive the acceptance of
the plant, and you say YES, then you
are a one with it and live under the
lifestyle of a doctor. Or if you are a
patient, you heal! It is time to test
yourself in real life!
Note: you don’t always have to say yes, or don’t always
get to an encounter with every plant.

Icaro Writing Excercise
Week 11
Oni Joi
Joi

 1.Invoke your doctor and it’s crown
Doctor

The crown

Putting on the crown

Noya Rao Medico
Shihuahuaco Medico
Mokapari (Chiric Sanango) Medico
Semei (Bobinsana) Medico
Joxo Pionis (Piñón Blanco) Medico
Wiso Pionis (Piñón Colorado) Medico

Inkaiko (Marosa) Medico

Min inin maiti
Min kori maiti
Min joe maiti
Min kewe maiti
Min joa maiti
Min pene maiti
-----------------------Min - Your
Inin - aromatic
Kori - gold
Joe - light
Kewe - Embroidered
Joa - Flower
Pene - Bright
Maiti (n) - Crown

Mai maishamanban
Mai maibainkin
-------------------------Maiti (v)- to crown oneself
-shaman (suffix, v): to do so
excellently
-ban (suffix, v): immediate
announcement
-bain (suffix, v): doing along the way
-kin (suffix, v): present participle,
more descriptive.
“I will crown myself excellently”
“I am crowning myself along the
way”

 2. It’s robe or tunic
The robe or tunic

Putting on the robe/tunic

Having put it on

inin tari ribikan
kori tari ribikan
joe tari ribikan
kewe tari ribikan
joa tari ribikan
pene tari ribikan
-------------------Inin - aromatic
Kori - gold
Joe - light
Kewe - Embroidered
Joa - Flower
Pene - Bright
tari - tunic or robe
ribi - also
-kan (suffix, n): this one, actually

Sawe saweshamanban
Sawe sawebainkin
Sawe saweshamankin
-------------------------------Saweti - to dress oneself
-shaman (suffix, v): to do so excellently
-ban (suffix, v): immediate
announcement
-bain (suffix, v): doing along the way
-kin (suffix, v): present participle, more
descriptive.

Saweyontaanara
-------------------------------Saweti - to dress oneself
-yon (suffix, v): to do fully, to
completion
-taana (suffix, v): having done so
-ra (suffix, v): emphatic

“Will dress excellently”
“Dressing along the way”
“Dressing excellently”

“Having fully dressed myself”

 3. It’s energetic belt, stole, or band
It’s energetic stole

Jawen niwe paoti
-----------------------Jawen - it’s
Niwe - wind-like energy
Paoti (n) - belt, stole, band
“It’s energetic belt, stole, or band”.

Describing the stole
inin niwe paoti
kori niwe paoti
joe niwe paoti
kewe niwe paoti
joa niwe paoti
pene niwe paoti
--------------------------Inin - aromatic
Kori - gold
Joe - light
Kewe - Embroidered
Joa - Flower
Pene - Bright
Niwe - wind-like energy
Paoti (n) - belt, stole, band

Putting it and becoming
doctor
Paoyonribataana, mion medicoyonban
----------------------------------------Paoti (v) - to put on a belt, stole or
band
-yon (suffix, v): to do fully, to
completion
-riba (suffix, v): once more, one more
time
-taana (suffix, v): having done so
“Having fully put on the belt, stole, or
band, one more time”
mion - towards you, destination of soft
impact (mia + on: towards, destination
of soft impact).
medicoti - to become doctor (spanish)
-ban (suffix, v): will do so immediately
“Will become your doctor immediately”

 4. Celebrate your embodiment
Doctor

Noya Rao Medico
Shihuahuaco Medico
Mokapari (Chiric Sanango) Medico
Semei (Bobinsana) Medico
Joxo Pionis (Piñón Blanco) Medico
Wiso Pionis (Piñón Colorado) Medico
Inoaxatan (Ayahuma) Medico
Inkaiko (Marosa) Medico

You

Ea xawebiribi
Ea nomabiribi
-----------------------Ea - I
xawe - gentleman
noma - woman (formal)
-biribi (suffix): one and only, with
affection
“I, the one and only gentleman”
“I, the one and only woman”

Celebration
Iki ishamani
Bewa Bewashamani
Medicoi Bewai
------------------------------iti - to be
-shaman (suffix, v): to do so
excellently
-i (suffix, v): present participle, -ing/
while doing so...
Bewati - to sing
Medicoti - to become a doctor
-ai (suffix, v): present tense
“Singing excellently”
“Singing excellently”
“Singing as I become doctor”

 5. Now the doctor appears
Now it appears
Rama ronki jishtiai
Nete meran jishtiai
-----------------------------Rama - now
ronki - they say
jishtiti - to appear
-ai (suffix, v): present tense
Nete - universe
meran - inside
“Now they saw I appear
I appear inside the realm”

Having appeared

Having Connected

Jishtiyontaanara
----------------------------------jishtiti - to appear
-yon (suffix, v): to do fully, to
completion
-taana (suffix, v): having done so
-ra (suffix, v): emphatic

Kanoyontaanara
-----------------------------Kanoti - to connect oneself
-yon (suffix, v): to do fully, to
completion
-taana (suffix, v): having done so
-ra (suffix, v): emphatic

“Having fully appeared”

“Having fully connected myself”

Bonus 2: Icaro by Shipibo Maestro Jaime – Koshinete

your body has healed

Bena Joi:
1 -neskara iki: it is like this (neskara: like this, in this manner)
2- benxo abanon: will heal another (benxo ati: to heal another, + banon: announcement.
Different from benxoti, to heal oneself).
3- neska neskashamankin: being like this excellently (neskati: to be or do in a certain way)
4- tseka tsekabokinra: taking out as I go (tsekati: to take out, remove)
5- isin: illness
6- jainxonki: right there. (Jain: there. -xon: in this case it is a suffix for emphasizing the place of
a transitive action. -ki: emphasis).
7- eon: fell lightly towards me (Ea + suffix -on: to fall lightly on, towards)
8-meax: from, adverb of place.
9-naman: below
10- tanita: standing in the foots of something, below something
11- torin ewa: huge towers (tori: tower, ewa: huge)
12- tsiri: a quality of beauty that denotes purity. Usually for women, children, flowers, birds.
13- tsoawa: a species of amazonian bird with medicinal significance.

 4 Dimensions

The dimension we live in. The
dimension of the land.

 4 Dimensions

Here inhabit the spirits of mermaids, water
chaikoni, water animals, anacondas, etc. It is a
dimension of its own.

Art by Pablo Amaringo

 4 Dimensions
Panshin Nete - Yellow World
This is the world of spirits. The
world we usually encounter when
training with master plants. This
world has duality. Here exist both
good and bad spirits.

 4 Dimensions

This is the realm we enter when we
come into contact with the divine.
It is pure and full of angels, saints,
royals, light, and divine elements.
The world of God.

Art by Pablo Amaringo

Bonus: Joi ronki Senenke – Koshinete

Jaskarabo orimpi3
raminaketiankan4
Poderonin5 panai

Panayontaanara x3

This is how they used to pray
when there was a possibility of distortion
God protects
Having fully protected
Once the cross in the body is fully done
Having made (the body) into towers fully
No one finds
They certainly find
The universe resounds
ending with joy
coming out with joy
coming out with all your name (all that you
are)

1. Xepoban – will close (Xepoti: to close. -ban: announcement, will)
2. Mananxawe – tortoise
3. Jaskarabaon orimpi – Jaskara: like this + -bo: plural suffix = in these ways. Orimpi: comes
from spanish “orar”, to pray.
4. Raminaketiankan- Rami: root of verb ramiti, to become distorted. -nake: suffix, denotes
possibility or potential to happen. -tian: suffix for time or a timeframe. -kan: suffix, this one
actually.
5. Poderonin – Podero: a way of referring to God (Allmighty, comes from spanish “Poderoso”).
-nin: suffix for pairing the transitive verb “panai”, in the sense that God is the protector, he is
the one doing the protecting.
6. Koros- cross. The healer draws crosses in the body symbolizing protection.
7. Torre – tower. From spanish. Alternatively “torri”. A tower represents the temples of heaven
and divine connection. The place where we meet the greatest spirit. When the body is “made
into” a tower it is being aligned to the greatest spirit.
8. Tsararanyabi – Tsararan is a resounding sound, like of bells, symbolizing celebration of
the arkana.

Completar lección

Introduction to Module 1
5 lessons

Week 1
11 lessons, 1 quiz

Icaro 3: Nokon Yora Panaban
Oni Joi
Joi

 Icaro: Nokon Yora Panaban
Shipibo-Konibo

English

Nokon yora panaban
Joiyabi panati
Ramitima abanon
Pisi piaxbikaya
Jawe iyosmakaya
Ea xawebiribi

I will protect my body
Protecting all my prayers
So they do not get distorted
As soon as I eat what smell rotten
Nothing happens
to me, the one and only gentleman

Jakonmabo piaxbi
Jawe iyosmakaya
Itsaboki piaxbi
Jawetianbikaya
Ramiyosma medico
Ea xawebiribi

Once I eat incompatible elements
Nothing happens
As soon as I eat what is with a pungent smell
Never
does it get distorted
me, the one and only gentleman

Ea kanobanonri
Bewakanbi ibanon
Inin ayontaana
Koshibira panati
Tsonbibiki merati
Meratima abanon

I will connect myself
I will sing with these songs
Having aromatized fully
The powerful protection
for no one to find me
No one will find me

Explanation
This is an icaro for sealing a healing
process. The healer is protecting
him/herself, and the medicine that is
contained in the icaros he sung. Anything
that comes in contact with the mouth,
whether it is food or body fluids form
sexual interaction, will not distort the
medicine of the icaro.

The curandero ends with connecting this
Arkana in himself. He sings for no one to
find him because this adds discretion to
his kano. You never know who can see
you and identify you and being protected
helps you become low-profile and of no
interest to those that want to potentially
harm.

 Key Words
Ati (v)
Bewa (n)
Ea (pron)
Inin ati (v)
Iti (v)
Itsa (adj)
Jakonma (adj)
Jawe (n)
Jawetianbi (adv)
Joi (n)
Kanoti (v)
Koshi (adj)
Medico (n)
Merati (v)
Nokon (pron)
Panati (v)
Pisi (adj)
Piti (v)
Ramiti (v)
Ramiyosma (adj)
Tsonbi (pron)
Xawe (n)
Yora (n)

Suffixes
to do
song
I
to perfume
to be
pungent smell
bad
what
never
voice, word
to connect itself
powerful, strong
doctor (from spanish)
to find
My
to protect
rotten smell
to eat
to distort
seldom gets distorted
no one
gentleman
body

-ax (v)
-ban/-banon (v)
-bi (n/v)
-biribi (n)
-bo (n/adj)
-i (v)
-kan (n)
-kaya (n/v)
-ki (n/adj)
-ma (n)
-ra (n/v/adj)
-taana (v)
-yabi (n)
-yon (v)
-yosma (v)

as soon as it’s done
immediate announcement
emphasis
one and only, affection
plural
present participle
emphasis, or using
truly, without doubt
towards
negation
emphasis
having done so
with all
doing an action fully
seldom does/is so

Suffixes -ax and -xon
Oni Joi

 Suffix -ax
The suffix -ax in Shipibo means “once it has been done...”, or “as
soon as it has happened”. It expresses a completed action and an
immediate subsequent action. It is a suffix widely used in both
icaros and spoken language. It is used to describe past events.
Example:
Noeshaman piax, ea tantia. ⟶ Once/As soon as I ate delicious
(food), I (immediately) rested.
*We know the rule that “tantiti” is an intransitive verb, so it uses the pronoun “ea”. The
general past does not require a -ra suffix.

 Suffix -xon
The suffix -xon in Shipibo is similar to the suffix -ax. It also means “once
I have done...”. However, the difference is that it expresses a completed
action and a not so immediate subsequent action. It is a suffix widely
used in both icaros and spoken language. It is also used to describe past
events.
Example:
Oni xeaxon, en jakon nete oina. ⟶ Once I drank Ayahuasca, I saw the
good universe.
*We know the rule that “ointi” is an transitive verb, so it uses the pronoun “en”. The general
past does not require a -ra suffix.

 Bena Joi
Nii - forest
Meran - inside
merati - to find
jaskatax - in this manner...
jakonti - to improve, become better
benxoti - to heal oneself
joxo pionis - piñón blanco

 Bena Joi
Nii

Benxoti

Meran

Jakonti

Merati

Jaskatax

Joxo Pionis

 Noeshaman piax,
ja tantia.

 Jakon chopa
tanaxon, en bia.

 Nii meran kaxon,
jan mesko keska
raobo meraa.

 Nama meran xobo
keras oinax, ea
raoboan poakata.
Jaskatax ea jakona.

*Dreaming of a dirty house signifies a distorted energy is in our body

 Nishi xeaxon, jan
jakon nete oina.

Jakon nete oinax,
ja bewaa.

 Nishi xeaxon, en
kinana.

 Kinanax, ea
benxoa.

 Joxo pionis
xeaxon, en
samata.

 Samatax, ea axea.

Icaro 3 Analysis Part 1
Oni Joi
Joi

 Icaro: Nokon Yora Panaban

Ea xawebiribi

does it get distorted
me, the one and only gentleman

for no one to find me

 Guide:

(pron): pronoun

(v): verb

 Nokon yora panaban

yora (n): body

panati (v): to
protect

I will protect my body

Joiyabi panati

word

with all

panati (v): to
protect

participle “-ing verb
ending”

Protecting with all my prayer
(panati, the verb that keeps the -t in the root makes it so that it is for yourself)

 Ramitima abanon

Ramiti (v): to get
distorted

Suffix (n):
negation

Ati (v): to
do

immediately

Will make it so it does not get distorted

Pisi
Pisi (adj/n):
rotting smell

piaxbikaya

Suffix (v): as soon Suffix (v):
as...

without a doubt

As soon as I certainly consume anything that smells rotten

 Jawe
Jawe (pron):
what,
something

iyosmakaya

Suffix (v): to seldom
do so

Suffix (v): certainly,
without a doubt

Nothing seldom happens, without a doubt

Ea xawebiribi
Ea (pron): I

Xawe (n):
gentleman

suffix (n): one and only,
with affection

(to) me, the one and only gentleman

umbrella term for intransitive verbs, in this case “to sing”.
